instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00281: What is 820-00281? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.3V3_G3H: What is 3V3_G3H? This is one of the first power rails that must turn on for Macbooks that use USB-C for charging. This power rail powers the CD3215 chip that controls the USB-C charger, speaks to the USB-C charger, and requests 20 volts up from the default 5 volts that the USB-C charger puts out when initially connected to an unknown device. .
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.820-00928: What is 820-00928? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Not charging, shows sign of battery flat
threads.message:
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not charging, 5V 0.02A on charger only (battery unplugged), 20V 0A with battery plugged, shows sign of battery flat.
Should be a simple problem to fix but...

Each USB-C port shows 5V with 0.02-3A consumption. No port power cycles.
When checking rails around the USB-C chip, I'm getting my 1.1V, 1.8V, 3.3V and 5V as expected.
PPBus does not have a short, .4V drop in diode mode.
I am getting 0.04V on PPBUS, floating.

I went ahead and replaced the SMC from a donor thinking there might be communication issue on those BI lines. No cigar.
I also went ahead and replaced the ISL. No cigar.
However I got that ISL 9239C0 from Aliexpress (original being 9239HI) but read that the 9239C0 should work just fine.

Though, noob question here...
Shall I be getting 20V before getting PPBus?

I assume yes and that's why I believe I went on the wrong road chasing no PPBus when I should be chasing why I am not getting 20V first.
Any good read on the Wiki or idea where to look at please?

Also I assume a short on some rail down the road is not on the list since I am getting the battery sign showing up with the battery plugged in.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Not charging, shows sign of battery flat
threads.message: Make sure you using a 87w charger and USB-C cable that is rated for 5 amps. You need to get 20v before worrying about no PPBUS on this board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Not charging, shows sign of battery flat
threads.message:
With charger alone, do you get <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> (L6900)?
Check <SIGNAL>SMC_USBC_INT_L</SIGNAL> level.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Not charging, shows sign of battery flat
threads.message:
[QUOTE="tcampbell34, post: 91696, member: 7922"]
Make sure you using a 87w charger and USB-C cable that is rated for 5 amps. You need to get 20v before worrying about no PPBUS on this board.
[/QUOTE]

Yes it is the original 87W charger. Tried both the customer charger and mine, same thing.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Not charging, shows sign of battery flat
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 91699, member: 682"]
With charger alone, do you get <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> (L6900)?
Check <SIGNAL>SMC_USBC_INT_L</SIGNAL> level.
[/QUOTE]
I am getting the 3.3V at the coil.
The <SIGNAL>SMC_USBC_INT_L</SIGNAL> is quickly jumping at 3.4V then right back down at 0.08V then 0.04V and stays there.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Not charging, shows sign of battery flat
threads.message:
I went ahead and replaced one more time the ISL from a donor this time. No change.

The resistor connecting <SIGNAL>SMC_USBC_INT_L</SIGNAL> to 3.3V is measuring fine. (I've checked other thread talking about a blown resistor)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Not charging, shows sign of battery flat
threads.message: Post <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> basic voltages (charger alone): <SIGNAL>P_IN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>AUX_DET</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>SMC_RST_IN</SIGNAL>, VDDA/P, <SIGNAL>SMC_RST</SIGNAL>*, IRQ*, <SIGNAL>AUX_OK</SIGNAL>, A/BMON.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Not charging, shows sign of battery flat
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Not charging, shows sign of battery flat
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>SMC_USBC_INT_L</SIGNAL>  is still a problem.
It keeps bloqued the SMC, which doesn't allow <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> to work.

Does it start in SMC bypass (charger alone)?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Not charging, shows sign of battery flat
threads.message:
Unfortunately it didn't make any difference doing the SMC bypass

I've checked with the thermal cam and nothing seems to be warming up.
The only area on this board that looks pretty corroded is the right wing (underneath) where the T1 controller is.
I've removed every corroded capacitor and reflowed the area, no luck.
Indeed that was to be expected since it will work on battery so no short I assume.

I've measured the surrounding components around <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> and all seem to measure fine.
I'm tempted to replace the SMC one more time since it's coming from one of these Chinese donors.

Anything else that I could be looking at knowing that <SIGNAL>SMC_USBC_INT_L</SIGNAL> signal is low?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Not charging, shows sign of battery flat
threads.message:
I went ahead and replaced one more time the SMC with a good known SMC and same behavior.
So my guess is that it is CD3215C00 related now since that signal only from the SMC to those ICs?!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Not charging, shows sign of battery flat
threads.message:
Test <RESISTOR>R3038</RESISTOR> with 1K, instead of 10K.
Check <RESISTOR>R3041</RESISTOR>/42 and <RESISTOR>R5320</RESISTOR>/21.
Also check diode mode to ground and voltage on that SMBUS "4".

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Not charging, shows sign of battery flat
threads.message:
I did replace the resistor and the signal is still pulled down. It did not make any difference in terms of voltage on the  <SIGNAL>SMC_USBC_INT_L</SIGNAL> side.
Those 4 resistors are measuring as they should.
I am getting around .53V drop on both <SIGNAL>SMBUS_SMC_4</SIGNAL> SCL and SDA signals.
Measuring .63V on known good board.

What are the odds that a <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> is the culprit?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Not charging, shows sign of battery flat
threads.message:
The <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips must release this signal.
There must be a reason, into USB-C areas, that doesn't allow that.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Not charging, shows sign of battery flat
threads.message:
You mentioned here ([URL]https://boards.rossmanngroup.com/threads/<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-stuck-on-5v.61038/post-74409[/URL]) that if I can get 20V when battery is connected, the USB-C circuitry should ne working, therefore I should be focusing on <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>.
Does that still apply?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Not charging, shows sign of battery flat
threads.message:
Until <SIGNAL>SMC_USBC_INT_L</SIGNAL> doesn't go high, I don't think to get it working with charger alone.
You can compare the behavior of this signal with similar boards.
